awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: U.S. Institutions after COVID-19: Trust, Accountability, and Public Perceptions
awd_abstract_narration:
COVID-19 upended social, economic, and political systems throughout the world. The United States has faced particular challenges due to its heterogeneity and federal nature. The COVID States project is a large-scale data collection that includes over-time data from diverse state-level samples. The project tracks state-level post-pandemic recovery, studying topics such as trust in institutions, information acquisition and impact, accountability, and economic inequality. It also documents how federal and state policies affect the populace when it comes to these topics. Further, the COVID States project provides access to researchers from all backgrounds, types of academic institutions, and career stages through a competition for survey module time and provides a user-friendly website with data trackers for use by researchers, students, journalists, policymakers, and the public.

The COVID States project conducts over-time state-level surveys from all 50 states and D.C. Each survey includes up to 30,000 total respondents, using quota sampling by state. This allows for generalizable inferences at the state and national levels. Post-pandemic data provide an unprecedented opportunity for novel over-time and across-space research designs. The project over-samples demographic minority respondents to facilitate study of heterogeneous social groups. This includes data on trust in political figures and institutions, knowledge and information, political evaluations, behavioral adaptation, physical health, economic well-being, mental health, and more. It also contains detailed social network batteries that allow for the study of inter-household and inter-group transmission of health and information. This is complemented by Twitter data from survey respondents who allow it. This enables the project to identify information sharing and study political discourse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on understanding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on public trust in institutions, democratic norms, government accountability, and information dissemination. During the course of the project, we conducted 29 waves of data collection across all 50 states and the District of Columbia, totaling over 500,000 responses.

Our large-scale, longitudinal data collection facilitated research at both the state and national levels. The oversampling of minority populations enabled us to reliably capture the attitudes and behaviors of diverse gender, age, racial, ethnic, and geographic groups. The initiative also allowed external researchers to leverage our data collection infrastructure by submitting their own modules to the survey.

The project resulted in a large number of publications, including more than 100 public-facing reports that received national media attention, over two dozen academic papers, a monograph, and an ongoing book project. The project's website, https://covidstates.org, serves as a hub for disseminating findings through reports, interactive dashboards, and aggregated data, ensuring public access to insights about COVID-19's social impact.

The initiative has additionally supported educational objectives by offering research experiences to undergraduate and graduate students. To share the experience gained from this project with a wider audience, project members also developed and taught a graduate course named “Pandemic Policy and Public Opinion.”

The team's efforts extended beyond academia, engaging with policymakers, public health officials, and the general public to share critical insights and data-driven analyses. Even as the immediate need for COVID-19 monitoring has waned, the project continues to share its findings.
